addressleaf.section:
M
r
Beales notes for
m
Bodleigh to deale with
e
D. of Brunswick

page.lettertext:
fol.174r
The g
e
t that is to bee sent
to the
Kinge of Denmarke
.
If he lande at
Embden
or
Hamburge
, to be directed to goe to the Duke
of Brunswig w
th
l
re
s and Credite from her
Ma
tie
to this effecte.
That wheras her Ma
tie
hathe sondrie tymes heretofore sent to the
princes of
Germanye
, that there might be some good confederac
o
n, union,
and intellig
e
ce betwene the princes and Estates professinge the christian
and reformed religion, to prevent the dessignes of the Councell of
Trent
, w
ch
she hathe a longe tyme forseen and admonished them
of, although there hathe not ben suche sucesse, as she could have
wished:
Yet seinge th'effectes therof appeare dailye more and more, both by the
late accid
e
tes in Germanye, and especially by the
Duke of Guises
att
e
ptes now in
Fraunce
:
Her Ma
tie
forseinge the d
a
nger ge
n
all, hathe thought good once
agayne to admonishe her good Coosins the princes of Germanye
therof.
And albeit her Ma
tie
hathe lesse Cause of feare then anie
of them have: yet her highnes preferringe the ge
n
all Cause
above anye
ticular respect, hathe vouchsafed agayne to sende into
those
tes:
And for her
te thinckethe it fitt, that there should be some c
o
ve-
ni
e
t place appoynted, (as
Erford
in
Turingia
, or some other Citye
theraboutes,) in the monethe of Julye next, where there might be
some Conference and consultac
o
n had about these Causes, to be sum
o
nd
by the c
o
sent of the three
Electo
rs
: wherto her Ma
tie
mindeth
to sende some speciall
son to signifie unto them her meaning more
fol.174v
at large:
And in the meane time hathe onlie sent a speciall messinger to the
Kinge of Denmarke, that he would joyne w
th
her in this action:
And doethe desire her good Coosen and Gossepp the Duke of
Brunswig, of his especiall good will towardes the further
a
nce
of good glorye, to sende the l
re
s directed to the
Electo
rs
of
Saxon
and
Brandeburge
, and
Lantgrave of Hessen
, (w
ch
she
hathe appoynted this Bearer to leave w
th
him), to the same
effecte: desiringe him to procure an aunswer from the said
Electo
rs
and princes, as speedelie as may be, and to sende the
same to some speciall place to be agreed on, when yo
w
shalbe
in his Courte, eyther at
Breme
or Hamburge, so as yo
w
maye
receyve the same at yo
r
retorne out of
Denmarke
, and her Ma
tie
maye be adv
r
tised of their det
r
minac
o
n, touchinge some suche ass
e
bly
as soone as maye be.
The said g
e
t to excuse this maner of sendinge, for that the
matter requirethe hast, and her Ma
tie
thinckethe, that her said
Coosen and
Gossepp
the Duke of Brunswig, is best able to deale
w
th
the said Electo
rs
, in respecte of the alli
a
nce and frendshipp
betwene them, and that in respecte of the greate care w
ch
he hathe
allwayes shewed to beare to gods Churche, and for his good will
towardes her Ma
tie
, he both can and will most commodiouslye
forme the same: and lykewise the said Electo
rs
and princes
take it in good
te:
The said Duke of Brunswig to be desired by the said
messinger; to im
te the Credence or negotiation, to the
Duke
fol.175r
Holsten
, the Dukes of
Pomer
, the
Duke of Mechleburg
, and
other princes, Erles, Cityes, and Estates makinge profession of
the Confession of
Augusta
in those
tes, to th'intent they maye
joyne in this action of sendinge &c to the assemblye.
And in the meane tyme, that the said princes and Estates, would
(as they have don manye tymes heretofore in the Civill warres
of Fr
a
nce &c inhibite under greate penalties the levyes
of horsemen or footemen to goe into Fr
a
nce or the
Lowe
C
o
ntreyes
, to serve anye
tie makinge profession of the c
o
trary
religion:
And lykewise desir
inge
them to consider, that these levyes
maye be afterwardes employed to the prejudice of the peace
of
Germanye
, and also of the Catholykes them selves, for
revenge of some
ticular quarrells, as
Grumbach
did
against the
Bishopp of Wirtzburg
.
To praye them also to have a care
and to take order
that seinge (god be
thancked) the late c
o
trov
r
sies about matters of religion are
well appeased,
to take order
that the ministers and preachers
in their jurisdictions, be not suffred by sermons, wrytinges, or
bookes, to refreshe the same quarrells: but rather to exhort
the people c
o
mitted unto their charge, unto peace and unitie &c.
fol.175v
The g
e
t that goeth to the Kinges
of Denmarke.
That forasmuchas the Duke of Holst his uncle, hathe
heretofore served the
Kinge of Spaine
under the
Duke of
Alva
, and maye leane that waye: that in respect of the c
o
mon
cause of religion, w
ch
the said Duke professethe, he would
empeache anie sendinge of forces out of his C
o
ntreye &c under
his said uncle, or anye other from him.
Forasmuchas if anye thinge should fall out w
th
Spayne
,
the amitie of the Esterlinges would be requisite, to empeache
him from corne and shippinge &c: to be considered, whether the
princes
well affected in Germany
might not be dealt w
th
to drawe them to this ass
e
bly
and the ambassado
rs
to have some cred
e
ce to deale in the same
causes w
th
the
Steedes
.
